title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: We proceeded towards Camelon, with the great ironworks of Carronilluminating the sky to our left, and finally arrived at Falkirk.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: Auchindary, Burhill Fort,Crowyhill, Westerwood, Castlecary (now a railway junction),Dick's House, Rough Castle, Camelon, Falkirk (with itsRoman tomb, pulled down in 1750), Mumrills, Kinniel

title: Tours in Scotland 1677 & 1681. By T. Kirk and R. Thoresby. Edited by P. Hume Brown
author: Kirk, Thomas
snippet: By some antiquariesthe ancient city of Camelon, of which Kirk speaks, is identified with theRoman Ad Vallum.

title: Tours in Scotland 1677 & 1681. By T. Kirk and R. Thoresby. Edited by P. Hume Brown
author: Kirk, Thomas
snippet: 2 Camelon now forms the western suburb of Falkirk.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
snippet: 1 A western suburb of Falkirk is still called Camelon.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
snippet: than two thousand men : not far from which place likewiseupon the river Carron was formerly situate the famous cityof Camelon,1 chief city of the Picts, founded by CruthneusCamelon before the birth of Christ 330 year, which wasdestroyed by King Kenneth the Great about the year ofChrist 846, and what was left was afterward swallowed upby an earthquake, where the void place is now filled withwater.
